ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.2_0: At that time a certain association was preparing an alms-meal at a public guesthouse not far from Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.3_0: Then, after robing up one morning, the monks from the group of six took their bowl and robe and entered Sāvatthī for alms. Not getting anything, they went to that public guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.4_0: And because it was long since they had been there, people served them respectfully.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.7_0: “What’s the point of returning to the monastery?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.8_0: Tomorrow we’ll just have to come back here.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.9_0: And so they stayed on and on right there, eating alms at the guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.10_0: With the ascetics of other religions:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.11_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.12_0: “How can these Sakyan ascetics stay on and on, eating alms at the guesthouse?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.13_0: We don’t prepare the alms-food just for them;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.15_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.16_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.17_0: “How can the monks from the group of six stay on and on at the guesthouse?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.18_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.21_0: “... Foolish men, how can you stay on and on, eating alms at the guesthouse?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.22_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.23_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.24.1_0: ‘If a monk eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.25_0: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Sāriputta was traveling in the Kosalan country toward Sāvatthī when he came to a public guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.2_0: And because it was long since they had been there, people served them respectfully.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.3_0: After he had eaten, Sāriputta became severely ill, and he was not able to leave that guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.4_0: On the second day, too, those people said to him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.7_0: the Buddha had prohibited eating alms at a public guesthouse after staying on and on, and because he was afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.9_0: When he arrived at Sāvatthī, he told the monks what had happened,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.10_0: They in turn told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.11_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.12_0: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to stay on at a public guesthouse and eat alms there.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.13_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.14.1_0: ‘If a monk who is not sick eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.2_0: he is able to leave that public guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.4_0: he is not able to leave that public guesthouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.6_0: as much as one needs of any of the five staple foods, prepared for the general public, in a building, under a roof-cover, at the foot of a tree, or out in the open.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.7_0: A monk who is not sick may eat there once.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.7_1: If he receives food beyond that with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.8_0: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.1_0: If he is not sick, and he does not perceive himself as sick, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.2_0: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.3_0: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.4_0: If he is sick, but he perceives himself as not sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.5_0: If he is sick, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.6_0: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.3_0: if he eats more than one who is not sick;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.4_0: if he leaves because he goes while coming;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.5_0: if he eats after being invited by the owners;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.6_0: if the food is prepared specifically for him;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.7_0: if there is not as much as he needs;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.8_0: if it is anything apart from the five kinds of staple food;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.10_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.11_0: The first rule, the training rule on alms-meals at public guesthouses, is finished.
